serviceName: Make a lasting power of attorney
startContent:
You can make a lasting power of attorney (LPA) using our online service.

If you want to, you can ask someone else to use the service for you, for example a family member, friend or solicitor. You will still need to make all the decisions about what goes on the LPA.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress so you do not need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.

It costs £82 to apply for an LPA.

Information you'll need

You may find it useful to gather some information before you start.

As well as your details, you’ll need the names, addresses and dates of birth of:

  • the attorneys
  • the replacement attorneys, if you decide to have any

You’ll also need the name and address of your certificate provider.

Documents, equipment and other things you'll need

You'll also need:

  • a debit or credit card to pay the application fee
  • a mobile phone, so we can text you a security code
  • documents or information to prove your identity
What you need to prove your identity

When you make an LPA, we need to check your identity. We do this to protect you and prevent fraud.

You can prove your identity by:

  • entering details from your passport or driving licence
  • entering details from, and uploading a photo of, a recent payslip or P60
  • signing in to your Government Gateway, Department for Work and Pensions, or online banking account, and letting us confirm your details with those organisations
  • taking documents to a Post Office
  • asking a professional (like a teacher, civil servant or solicitor) to confirm your identity

whichTypeOfLpaToMake: Which type of LPA do you want to make?
whichTypeOfLpaToMakeContent:
There are 2 types of LPA: finance and affairs, and personal welfare. You can have one or both.

They do not have to be made at the same time and you can choose different attorneys for each LPA.

You'll be able to reuse any information you enter to make other LPAs later.

Find out more about the 2 types of LPAs
lpaTypePfaHint: This covers decisions about your money and property
lpaTypeHwHint: This covers decisions about your health care, medical treatment and personal welfare
selectLpaType: Select the type of LPA to make
taskListHelpContent:
There's help included with every question, and you can also read our full guide to making an LPA.

You may want to look at our before you begin help page. It explains the decisions you have to make about your LPA and the information you’ll need to provide.

We’ll save the LPA as you progress - you don't need to complete it in one go. You can sign out at any time and come back later.

whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneys: Who would you like to be the attorneys?
whoWouldYouLikeToBeTheAttorneysContent:
Your attorneys are the people who'll be able to help you make decisions about your finances, if you ever want or need their help in the future.

It's important that you choose people you trust to respect your wishes and act in your best interests.

You can have more than 1 attorney. Most people have between 1 and 3.

An attorney must:

  • be aged 18 or over
  • have mental capacity (be able to make decisions)

Someone cannot be an attorney if they are:

  • bankrupt or have a debt relief order
  • on the Disclosure and Barring Service barred list (someone is normally put on this list if they have a criminal conviction or caution that means they’re not allowed to work with vulnerable people)

You'll be asked if you would like to add replacement attorneys in a separate question. These would step in if the original attorneys are unable or unwilling to continue.

Find out more about attorneys
wantReplacementAttorneys: Do you want any replacement attorneys?
wantReplacementAttorneysContent:
Replacement attorneys step in if one of your original attorneys dies or has to step down from the role.

Having replacement attorneys is optional, however, having 1 or more helps make sure your LPA will keep working if Pat Taylor (your original attorney) has to step down.

A replacement attorney must meet the same requirements as an original attorney. This includes being 18 or over.

Find out more about replacement attorneys.
selectWantReplacementAttorneys: Select whether you want any replacement attorneys
whenCanTheLpaBeUsed: When can the LPA can be used?
whenCanTheLpaBeUsedContent:
You can decide whether you want your attorney to be able to use the LPA as soon as it's registered or only once you've lost mental capacity.

As soon as the LPA is registered

Most people choose this option as it’s the most practical. It means Pat Taylor (your attorney) can use the LPA:

  • if you lose mental capacity
  • when you have mental capacity, but only if you give them permission to do something

This option is useful in case there are times in the future when you're able to make your own decisions, but need help with certain things. For example, if it ever became difficult for you to visit the bank or talk on the phone, you might ask Pat to use the LPA to deal with the bank or pay bills.

Only when you've lost mental capacity

This option means Pat can only use the LPA if you have lost mental capacity.

Be careful, as this can make the LPA a lot less useful. Each time Pat tries to use the LPA, they might be asked to prove that you do not have mental capacity.
whenDoYouWantAttorneysToUse: When do you want the attorneys to be able to use the LPA?

selectWhenCanTheLpaBeUsed: Select when the LPA can be used
restrictionsOnYourAttorneysPowerContent:
You can add 'restrictions' to the LPA - this is optional.

Restrictions guide the way the attorneys make decisions. They tell the attorneys what:

  • they must or must not do, when they’re making certain decisions on your behalf
  • you would like them to consider when they’re making certain decisions
restrictionExamplesContent:
Example restrictions: things the attorneys must or must not do

  • 'My attorneys must only invest my money in ethical funds'
  • 'My attorneys must not sell my home unless, in my doctor's opinion, I can no longer live independently.'

Example restrictions: things the attorneys should consider

  • 'I'd like my attorneys to consider ethical funds when investing my money'
  • I would like my attorneys to consult my doctor if they believe I may not have mental capacity to make decisions about my house.
restrictionsTooLong: Restrictions must be 10,000 or fewer characters
whoDoYouWantToBeCertificateProviderGuida:
Who do you want to be your certificate provider?

A certificate provider is an independent person who talks to you to check you understand your LPA and want to make it.

Most people choose a friend to be their certificate provider.

What your certificate provider has to do

Your certificate provider has to:

  • confirm their identity
  • read the LPA once you've finished making it
  • meet you in person to talk about the LPA in private
  • witness you signing the LPA

We’ll then ask the certificate provider to:

  • confirm they’ve discussed the LPA with you
  • tell us if they have any concerns about the LPA - for example, if they think someone is pressuring you to make it

We call this 'providing a certificate'. They can do this using our online service or a paper form.

If we ever have any concerns about the LPA, we may ask the certificate provider to tell us more about the conversation they had with you.

Who to choose as your certificate provider

You can choose either:

  • someone you’ve known well for at least 2 years, for example, a friend or neighbour (but not a relative)
  • a doctor, lawyer or another professional with the skills to check whether you understand the LPA

Choose someone:

  • you’re comfortable having an open, honest conversation with
  • who will speak up if they think something is wrong

Who cannot be a certificate provider

Your certificate provider cannot be:

  • under 18 years old
  • an attorney on your LPA
  • related to you or Pat (this includes step-relations, in-laws, husbands, wives, partners, boyfriends and girlfriends)
  • your or Pat's business partner or employee
  • someone who works for a care home where you live, or their relative

Find our more about certificate providers, and who can and cannot take on the role.
certificateProviderDetailsHint: Remember, the certificate provider must be 18 or over. They cannot be a member of your family (this includes step-relations and in-laws) or of the attorneys' families.
certificateProviderDobHint: We need the certificate provider's date of birth to check they are over 18.
